GUE_NGL condemns the subordination of freedom of expression to internal market rules, as Article 2(7) grants the European Court of Justice authority over civil liberties.  
GUE_NGL opposes the prioritization of corporate interests over user rights, allowing service providers to impose restrictions via contractual terms (Annex IV).  
GUE_NGL declares the procedural framework incompatible with democratic principles, as it institutionalizes surveillance risks under Recital 22.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the joint text negotiated through the conciliation process, which reconciled differing positions on the Commission’s amended proposal (COM(2008)0724) and the Council’s common position. It formally adopted the finalized legislative act, instructing its President to sign it jointly with the Council’s President under Article 254(1) of the EC Treaty, thereby finalizing the legislative procedure. The Parliament further directed its Secretary-General to verify procedural compliance, coordinate with the Council’s Secretary-General to publish the act alongside the Commission’s explanatory statement in the Official Journal of the EU, and ensure transparency. Additionally, it mandated its President to transmit the resolution to the Council and Commission, concluding the legislative process initiated under the Commission’s original proposal (COM(2007)0697) and subsequent amendments.

title: Online consumer dispute resolution: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes (Regulation on consumer ODR)
background: Growing cross-border e-commerce in the EU faced challenges with consumer trust due to inconsistent national alternative dispute resolution mechanisms and obstacles in resolving transnational disputes efficiently. The Parliament will discuss establishing an EU-wide online dispute resolution framework to standardize consumer protection and facilitate accessible redress mechanisms for digital transactions.

stances.stance:
EPP fully supports the issue's establishment of a pan-European ODR platform, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eliminating internal market barriers through efficient consumer protection mechanisms.  
EPP highlights the issue's 90-day dispute issue timeframe as a transformative advancement that effectively advances EPP's priority of judicial efficiency and consumer trust in cross-border commerce.  
EPP applauds the mandatory multilingual accessibility of the ODR interface, recognizing this as critical for ensuring equal consumer rights across all member states in line with single market principles.  
EPP emphasizes the issue's compatibility with successful national ADR models like Baden-Württemberg's online mediation system, demonstrating its practical alignment with proven market-enhancing tools.  
EPP commends the inclusion of post-service employment safeguards for ADR personnel as essential for maintaining expert dispute issue quality while upholding ethical standards.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the establishment of a standardized 90-day issue framework, which decisively advances consumer rights across the EU internal market.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the multilingual interactive web portal as a critical step toward equitable access to justice, aligning perfectly with their commitment to linguistic inclusivity and digital empowerment.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing public awareness campaigns to address historically low ADR adoption rates, ensuring the platform’s benefits reach all consumers without opposing the issue’s core mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the single-entry point design for out-of-court settlements, recognizing its potential to reduce bureaucratic fragmentation and empower vulnerable consumers.  
GREEN_EFA affirms that the issue’s focus on cost-effective dispute issue directly mirrors their manifesto goals of economic fairness and procedural transparency in cross-border transactions.

ALDE strongly advocates the establishment of EU-wide mediation procedures, which align perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to fostering consumer confidence and stimulating cross-border economic activity through efficient dispute issue.  
ALDE applauds the recognition of internal enterprise mediators in member states, emphasizing that strict independence criteria must be rigorously enforced to prevent conflicts of interest and ensure impartial outcomes.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the online platform’s accessibility by mandating direct integration with the "Europe is there for you" portal and requiring multilingual support to lower barriers for consumers and SMEs.  
ALDE underscores the critical need for coordinated awareness campaigns to ensure both consumers and businesses fully understand their mediation rights under the new framework, particularly regarding opt-out tribunal options.  
ALDE highlights the importance of monitoring mediator appointment processes to maintain quality standards, advocating for transparent accreditation systems across all member states.

SD entirely approves the ODR platform’s multilingual, cost-free accessibility and robust privacy safeguards, perfectly aligning with their commitment to equitable consumer protection in the digital single market.  
SD highlights the necessity of swift national transposition and awareness campaigns to ensure uniform ODR implementation, reflecting their dedication to harmonized consumer rights across the EU.  
SD applauds the issue’s emphasis on mediator independence and procedural transparency, which advance their longstanding priority of institutional accountability in dispute issue.  
SD underscores the critical role of monitoring ODR case patterns to proactively address systemic market issues, aligning with their data-driven approach to consumer policy enhancement.  
SD emphasizes the platform’s alignment with linguistic inclusivity and accessibility for vulnerable consumers, resonating with their manifesto pledge to eliminate barriers in cross-border commerce.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0794) concerning internal market and consumer protection measures, endorsing the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s report and the Committee on Legal Affairs’ opinion. It formally adopted its stance, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending to introduce substantial amendments or replace it, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and alignment with EU legislative frameworks.

title: Package travel and assisted travel arrangements: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and assisted travel arrangements, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004, Directive 2011/83/EU and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC
background: The 1990 EU Package Travel Directive, predating widespread internet use, lacked provisions for online bookings and dynamic travel packages, creating consumer protection gaps. The European Commission proposed modernizing rules in 2013 to address digital market developments. The Parliament will discuss updating consumer safeguards for package travel and assisted arrangements in the digital era.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the harmonized price adjustment thresholds in Articles 4-6, which align perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to consumer protection by limiting post-booking surcharges to 3% and granting cancellation rights beyond 8% increases.  
EPP approves the integration of consumer rights directive elements into the package travel framework, effectively advancing EPP's priority of regulatory coherence in cross-border services.  
EPP endorses the cross-border liability provisions that protect travelers in insolvency cases, particularly benefiting small member states with high tourism dependency as emphasized in the Slovenian and Croatian interventions.  
EPP acknowledges the issue's balanced approach to data protection requirements while proposing enhanced guidance for SMEs on implementing privacy safeguards without overburdening operators.  
EPP highlights the need for technical clarifications in Recital 17 regarding online-offline parity, suggesting future refinement of "click-through" vs "stand-alone" service definitions to ensure market fairness.

GREEN_EFA absolutely endorses the issue's harmonization of consumer protection standards as perfectly aligning with their commitment to transparent market practices that preserve diverse travel services.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on transparency over uniform regulation, effectively advancing their priority of empowering informed consumer choices while safeguarding market diversity.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the achieved balance in differentiating between package travelers and self-organizers as critical to maintaining accessible services, consistent with their ecological-social market principles.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's success in rejecting overprotective measures that risk stifling innovation, reinforcing their stance on proportionate consumer safeguards.  
 While expressing procedural concerns about legislative timing, GREEN_EFA treats this as an enhancement opportunity for future implementation reviews rather than opposing the substance.

ALDE completely accepts the issue as it perfectly aligns with their commitment to harmonized consumer protection and digital market efficiency.  
ALDE highlights the achieved clarity on liability as a critical advancement for both businesses and travelers in the digital age.  
ALDE acknowledges future opportunities to refine distinctions between online and offline bookings while maintaining the current balanced framework.  
ALDE applauds the inclusion of dynamic packages and linked travel arrangements as essential modernization for fair competition.  
ALDE urges rejection of disruptive amendments to preserve the directive’s alignment with treaty objectives and market stability.

SD strongly advocates the issue's modernization of consumer protections for digital travel bookings, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to safeguarding citizens' rights in evolving markets.  
SD applauds the enhanced liability clarity for businesses, which effectively advances both consumer confidence and market stability in line with SD's priorities.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to expand the directive's scope in future revisions to address emerging travel business models and ensure comprehensive safeguards.  
SD proposes strengthening compensation guarantees by adopting Amendment 100, ensuring travelers' right to terminate contracts in cases of extraordinary personal circumstances such as illness or family emergencies.  
SD highlights the issue's requirements for clear contractual terms and customer contact points as foundational steps toward improving on-site assistance during travel disruptions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0512) concerning measures under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union to harmonize internal market rules, following assessments by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and consultations with other committees and bodies. The resolution emphasized the need to align legislation with treaty objectives, reflecting input from the European Economic and Social Committee and procedural adherence to parliamentary rules. It formally adopted its stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text, and instructed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to advance legislative proceedings.

title: Protection of consumers in utilities services: REPORT on consumer protection – protection of consumers in utilities services
background: The European Union has established sector-specific consumer protection frameworks for energy, telecommunications, postal services, and public transport, with directives requiring national implementation. Persistent challenges in market transparency, service accessibility, and vulnerable consumer inclusion across member states preceded parliamentary consideration. The Parliament will discuss strengthening consumer safeguards in essential utilities services under existing EU legislation.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue’s failure to break Council deadlocks on market surveillance reforms, perpetuating weak cross-border consumer protections.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the flawed origin labeling provisions that mislead consumers instead of enabling genuine product traceability, contradicting transparency pledges.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely challenges with any dilution of "made in" requirements, which are indispensable for ecological relocalization and consumer empowerment.  
GREEN_EFA criticizes the prioritization of bureaucratic processes over actionable mechanisms to strengthen consumer rights enforcement.  
GREEN_EFA demands binding traceability standards rather than superficial labeling, aligning with their vision for sustainable supply chains.

ALDE strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on reducing bureaucratic burdens for SMEs, proposing to amend Article 7 by replacing mandatory "EU safety tested" markings with risk-based testing protocols to maintain product safety without unnecessary compliance costs.  
ALDE strongly sanctions the issue’s market surveillance improvements, aligning with ALDE's priority of streamlined procedures that enhance consumer protection while maintaining free movement of goods.  
ALDE strongly sanctions maintaining "Made in" as a voluntary quality indicator rather than a safety requirement, proposing to preserve it as a trademark system separate from product safety regulations.  
ALDE strongly sanctions combating protectionism through smarter labeling rules, advocating for origin disclosure only where materially relevant to safety to avoid trade distortions.  
ALDE strongly sanctions the issue’s digital single market goals, urging faster implementation of ODR systems to match ALDE’s 2023 manifesto commitments on consumer redress.

SD strongly sanctions enhanced product safety measures, particularly mandatory origin labeling and traceability systems, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to protecting vulnerable consumers like children and the elderly.  
SD approves the issue's focus on energy transparency but proposes reinstating explicit provisions on energy poverty to address rising costs impacting low-income households.  
SD endorses pan-European injury databases and unified safety standards as critical tools to eliminate hazardous products, effectively advancing SD's priority of evidence-based consumer protection.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of strict enforcement mechanisms for market surveillance, including penalties for non-compliance, to ensure a level playing field for ethical businesses.  
SD applauds the precautionary principle integration in utility regulations, urging swift implementation of smart metering systems with robust data protection safeguards.

ECR fully promotes the issue's emphasis on balanced regulation that protects consumers without imposing disproportionate burdens on businesses, perfectly aligning with their commitment to market efficiency.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue's call for rigorous implementation of existing directives on energy security and vulnerable consumer protections, as highlighted in Croatia's need for enforcement frameworks.  
ECR fully promotes the prioritization of transparent pricing and simplified provider switching in telecom/energy markets, mirroring their focus on consumer empowerment through competitive choices.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue's smart metering provisions that respect data protection, reinforcing their stance on innovation paired with individual privacy safeguards.  
ECR fully promotes the rejection of excessive product bans that stifle innovation, proposing enhanced risk assessments instead of blanket prohibitions on non-food items resembling foodstuffs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to strengthen consumer rights and ensure access to affordable, high-quality utility services across the EU, emphasizing energy, telecommunications, postal services, and public transport. It stressed the importance of fully implementing existing directives, including the Consumer Rights Directive (2011/83/EU) by June 2014, the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive (2005/29/EC), and measures to enforce consumer rights through alternative dispute resolution (ADR) and online dispute resolution (ODR) systems. The resolution highlighted the necessity of transparent pricing, simplified switching of energy and telecom providers, and enhanced consumer information campaigns, particularly for vulnerable consumers, who may require tailored support. In energy, it called for timely implementation of the third internal energy market package to achieve competitive prices, security of supply, and sustainability, alongside smart metering systems that respect consumer choice and data protection. For telecommunications, it advocated easier provider switching without fees, improved service transparency, and bridging the digital divide. Postal services were urged to enhance delivery reliability, interoperability, and cost efficiency, while public transport policies should prioritize accessibility for the elderly and people with limited mobility, aligning with climate goals. The resolution also underscored the role of independent consumer organizations and balanced regulation to protect consumers without overburdening service providers.

title: Public procurement: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on public procurement
background: The EU's public procurement framework, governing 18% of GDP, faced calls for modernization to address legal fragmentation, inefficiencies, and evolving market needs. National parliaments raised subsidiarity concerns, while cross-border procurement complexities and post-2008 budgetary pressures highlighted gaps in existing directives. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing procurement rules to improve transparency, competition, and administrative flexibility.

stances.stance:
EFD fundamentally disputes with the harmonization approach in Articles 53(1) and 114 TFEU, which undermines local business protections through excessive cross-border competition.  
EFD rejects the issue's failure to implement concrete "kilometro zero" thresholds that would prioritize regional enterprises amid Italy's 40% youth unemployment crisis.  
EFD opposes the absence of binding subcontracting limits in mutual recognition frameworks, creating loopholes exploited by criminal organizations through unregulated labor chains.  
EFD highlights the proposal's non-compliance with subsidiarity principles raised by national parliaments, particularly regarding port concessions and service sector disparities between Germany and Italy.  
EFD condemns the bureaucratic focus on "streamlined procedures" that ignores real-world administrative failures, as evidenced by Parliament's 18-month hemicycle repair procurement debacle.

ALDE fundamentally upholds the modernization of EU procurement rules through this directive, perfectly aligning with its commitment to a competitive single market with reduced administrative barriers for SMEs.  
ALDE highlights the issue's success in preserving municipal cooperation models while preventing unfair public-private competition, effectively advancing regional economic cohesion.  
ALDE applauds the explicit exclusion of water services from privatization requirements and emergency rescue services from tendering rules, securing vital public service continuity as outlined in Article 9 revisions.  
ALDE emphasizes the issue's breakthrough in replacing lowest-cost bidding with economically advantageous criteria, a reform long championed in its market efficiency agendas.  
 While welcoming reduced upfront documentation for SMEs, ALDE proposes monitoring implementation to ensure national authorities fully adopt self-declaration mechanisms per Article 7(2).

SD absolutely agrees the exclusion of water services from the concessions directive, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to safeguarding public control over essential services as demonstrated by the successful European Citizens' Initiative.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's shift from lowest-price criteria to economically most advantageous offers, advancing SD's priority of integrating social, environmental, and quality standards in public procurement.  
SD absolutely agrees the binding social clauses requiring compliance with collective bargaining agreements and environmental obligations throughout subcontracting chains, effectively advancing workers' rights across member states.  
SD perfectly supports the simplified electronic procurement procedures and SME access provisions, which align with SD's longstanding commitment to reducing administrative barriers for small businesses in EU markets.  
SD absolutely agrees the legal clarity maintaining public authorities' autonomy in organizing services of general economic interest, consistent with SD's principles of subsidiarity and territorial cohesion.

GUE_NGL partially accepts the social/environmental criteria in procurement but demands amendments to Article 15c requiring quality standards as binding minimum thresholds.  
GUE_NGL fully disputes concessions directive provisions enabling marketization of public services, contradicting their anti-privatization principles for essential resources like water.  
GUE_NGL requests mandatory parliamentary debate before trilogue negotiations, citing democratic erosion through procedural bypasses of legislative scrutiny.  
GUE_NGL highlights unresolved contradictions in prioritizing corporate competition over SME protections in public contracts, failing to address employment safeguards raised in João Ferreira's intervention.  
GUE_NGL requires strengthened cross-border enforcement mechanisms against tax-evading contractors, proposing explicit exclusion clauses for entities violating collective bargaining agreements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2011)0896) aimed at harmonizing rules for the recognition of professional qualifications across EU member states, grounded in Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union Articles 53(1), 62, and 114. It acknowledged objections from the UK House of Commons and Swedish Parliament contesting compliance with subsidiarity principles, while incorporating opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urging the Commission to ensure mutual recognition frameworks balance labor mobility with public safety and consumer protection. It emphasized the need for streamlined administrative procedures, enhanced transparency in qualification assessments, and reinforced mechanisms for cross-border disciplinary information sharing. Parliament further called on the Commission to revisit the proposal through renewed parliamentary scrutiny if substantial revisions arise and directed its President to formally communicate the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national legislatures.

title: Recognition of professional qualifications and administrative cooperation through the Internal Market Information System: REPORT proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2005/36/EC on the recognition of professional qualifications and Regulation on administrative cooperation through the Internal Market Information System
background: Persistent barriers to cross-border labor mobility within the EU single market, stemming from divergent national regulations on professional qualifications and administrative coordination inefficiencies, prompted legislative review. The Parliament will discuss updating the 2005 framework to harmonize recognition processes and strengthen cooperation mechanisms for regulated professions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the introduction of the European Professional Card as a transformative tool to enhance worker mobility and align with the EU’s single market objectives, echoing Constance Le Grip’s emphasis on operationalizing citizenship rights.  
EPP applauds the streamlined recognition procedures for nurses and dual education systems, aligning with Andreas Schwab’s commitment to maintaining high training standards while addressing sector-specific labor shortages.  
EPP proposes reinforcing Article 7 to explicitly link qualification frameworks with national education reforms, addressing Milan Zver’s call for comparable learning outcomes to prevent recognition disparities.  
EPP emphasizes rigorous monitoring of unemployment data transparency to prevent member states from misrepresenting workforce outflows, reflecting Zdravka Bušić’s caution against statistical manipulation.  
EPP endorses automatic recognition mechanisms for pre-2004 nursing qualifications highlighted by Elżbieta Łukacijewska, ensuring equal access to labor markets for Polish healthcare professionals.

EFD fully disputes the proposal's erosion of national professional sovereignty, exemplified by risks to Italy's culturally vital tour guide sector.  
EFD rejects the issue's failure to prevent discriminatory qualification non-recognition, as demonstrated by the unjust treatment of UK ski instructors in France.  
EFD highlights the proposal's threat to cultural heritage preservation by enabling unqualified "pseudo-guides" through cross-border loopholes.  
EFD condemns the framework's inconsistency with subsidiarity principles, directly conflicting with protections for member states' unique professional landscapes.  
EFD asserts the text overlooks critical worker protections, enabling administrative harassment of qualified professionals under flawed mutual recognition mechanisms.

ECR strongly sanctions the streamlined recognition procedures for professionals, particularly the inclusion of essential safety checks for health workers to ensure patient safety and communication standards.  
ECR applauds the establishment of an EU-wide alert mechanism as proposed in the issue, which aligns with their commitment to maintaining high professional standards while enabling mobility.  
ECR emphasizes the importance of the voluntary electronic professional card system to simplify verification processes, proposing enhanced interoperability between national databases for seamless implementation.  
ECR endorses the alignment of minimum training requirements across Member States, recognizing this as critical to eliminating discriminatory barriers and advancing single market principles.  
ECR highlights the need for consistent application of language competency assessments to build consumer trust, urging explicit guidelines in Annex VII to prevent divergent national interpretations.

GUE/NGL partly accepts the inclusion of language safeguards for healthcare professions but requests revisions to prevent uniform minimum standards from eroding national qualification systems.  
GUE/NGL totally opposes with the proposal’s market-driven approach, which prioritizes employer cost-cutting over worker protections and risks degrading service quality through lowered training benchmarks.  
GUE/NGL opposes the issue’s failure to address wage suppression mechanisms inherent in cross-border labor competition, inconsistent with their commitment to social equity.  
GUE/NGL demands amendments to Article 4 to explicitly prohibit member states from bypassing higher national qualification requirements, safeguarding against a “race to the bottom” in professional training.  
GUE/NGL rejects the framing of worker mobility as a tool for market efficiency, stressing the need to prioritize upward harmonization of labor rights over administrative convenience for employers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2011)0883) on harmonizing national measures affecting the internal market, emphasizing compliance with Treaty provisions (Articles 46, 53(1), 62, and 114 TFEU). It noted objections from the French Senate under Protocol No 2, which argued the proposal breached subsidiarity, and referenced the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2012 opinion. Parliament adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to prioritize legal clarity, proportionality, and alignment with EU freedoms, particularly for workers and services. It insisted the Commission must resubmit the proposal to Parliament if making substantial amendments, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution also directed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring adherence to legislative procedures and interinstitutional accountability.

title: Textile names and related labelling of textile products: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on textile names and related labelling of textile products
background: Existing EU textile labeling rules, established through multiple directives, faced fragmentation due to varied national transpositions, complicating market access for innovative fibers and consumer clarity. The European Commission proposed replacing directives with a regulation to harmonize standards. The Parliament will discuss standardizing textile product labeling requirements to enhance internal market efficiency and consumer information transparency.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly agrees the mandatory origin labelling system for third-country textiles as a critical safeguard for consumer transparency and SME protection.  
EPP perfectly aligns with provisions accelerating market access for innovative fibres while maintaining strict EU safety standards for allergenic substance controls.  
EPP champions the "Made in Europe" optional label as a non-protectionist quality benchmark that reinforces worker rights and environmental compliance.  
EPP applauds the issue’s harmonisation of textile names across Article 114 TFEU as essential for reducing administrative burdens and boosting intra-EU competitiveness.  
EPP proposes strengthening digital traceability mechanisms in recital 18 to enhance supply chain visibility without delaying implementation timelines.

GREEN_EFA rejects the inclusion of origin marking provisions as incompatible with maintaining a functional textile labeling framework.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally condemns with attempts to expand the directive's scope, citing proven Council resistance risks that would delay novel fiber transparency measures.  
GREEN_EFA opposes merging origin labeling with material nomenclature, arguing this jeopardizes both objectives by reviving unresolved political deadlocks.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal's failure to address origin marking through dedicated legislative channels as required by their consumer protection principles.  
GREEN_EFA insists on separating novel fiber identification reforms from broader "Made in" debates to prevent procedural collapse.

SD strongly accepts the harmonization of textile labelling rules under Article 114 TFEU, aligning with the party’s commitment to consumer transparency and internal market efficiency. The issue’s emphasis on 100% fibre composition lists directly advances SD priorities for empowering informed consumer choices.  

SD proposes enhancing origin labelling provisions by amending Article 4 to include “made in” disclosures, reinforcing ethical production standards and addressing concerns about child labor—a critical enhancement opportunity consistent with SD’s social justice principles.  

SD approves the mandate for future studies on comprehensive textile labelling, urging the Commission to integrate sizing standardization into this review to further boost cross-border trade, reflecting SD’s proactive stance on consumer-centric market integration.  

SD applauds the issue’s alignment with innovation-driven textile manufacturing, advocating for a subsequent EU monitoring body to oversee allergen testing and safety compliance, thereby strengthening health protections without opposing the regulation’s core framework.  

SD emphasizes the necessity of binding timelines for implementing labelling reforms, suggesting Annex II be amended to require biennial progress reports—a minor procedural adjustment to ensure sustained accountability in line with SD’s governance values.

ECR rejects the inclusion of country-of-origin marking requirements as totally disapproveing with their commitment to market efficiency and regulatory simplification.  
ECR opposes the rapporteur's expansion of the proposal's scope, arguing it introduces unnecessary complexities inconsistent with ECR's focus on lean legislation.  
ECR contends that attaching non-core amendments like origin labelling undermines the directive's primary goal of harmonizing textile trade across the EU internal market.  
ECR asserts the issue's diversion into political symbolism overlooks critical industry cost savings and faster product approvals central to ECR's economic priorities.  
ECR totally disapproves with provisions treating textile labelling as a platform for broader protectionist agendas rather than technical standardization.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting at first reading the proposed legislation based on the Commission’s 2009 proposal (COM(2009)0031), aimed at harmonizing internal market regulations under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The resolution emphasized the need to align the proposal with the Treaty of Lisbon’s implications (COM(2009)0665) and incorporated input from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements were planned, ensuring procedural continuity. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional cooperation and transparency in the legislative process.

title: Procurement by entities operating in the water, energy, transport and postal services sectors: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on procurement by entities operating in the water, energy, transport and postal services sectors
background: The EU’s existing procurement framework for water, energy, transport, and postal services, governed by sector-specific rules established in the 2000s, faced calls for modernization to address legal ambiguities, market fragmentation, and evolving public service demands. The Parliament will discuss reforms to procurement procedures for entities operating in these sectors, aimed at modernizing rules and streamlining cross-border competition.

stances.stance:
EFD slightly advocates the directive but requests revisions to Article 7 to impose strict limits on subcontracting, citing risks of organized crime infiltration through unrestricted supply chains.  
EFD firmly disputes harmonization clauses under TFEU Articles 53/114 as violating subsidiarity principles, aligning with Swedish and UK parliamentary objections to centralized market intervention.  
EFD rejects the cross-border procurement model for failing to protect local SMEs, demanding amended thresholds in Annex II favoring "kilometre zero" businesses and municipal autonomy.  
EFD highlights contradictions in environmental enforcement by allowing non-EU bids that exploit labor conditions, requiring strict origin criteria in Article 19(2)(c) mirroring domestic standards.  
EFD questions enforcement mechanisms, noting Parliament's own procurement failures with the Brussels hemicycle repairs as evidence of systemic bureaucratic inefficiency.

ALDE absolutely upholds the modernization of procurement procedures as perfectly aligning with their commitment to a competitive single market while preserving municipal autonomy.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's SME facilitation measures, particularly reduced financial thresholds and lot division, which directly advance their 2023 priority of entrepreneurial growth.  
ALDE absolutely upholds the clarification exempting water services from privatization mandates, effectively advancing their longstanding principle of subsidiarity in critical infrastructure.  
ALDE perfectly supports the integration of social/environmental award criteria as a strategic enhancement to combat wage dumping while maintaining procurement efficiency.  
ALDE absolutely upholds the exemption for non-profit emergency services, strengthening their manifesto pledge to protect civic engagement and volunteer-based models.

SD totally advocates the exclusion of water services from the directive's scope, perfectly aligning with their commitment to safeguarding public control over essential services as demonstrated by supporting the Right2Water citizen initiative.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on social and environmental criteria, endorsing mandatory compliance with collective bargaining agreements and international labor standards for all concession operators and subcontractors.  
SD fully supports the shift from lowest-price to economically advantageous tenders, which enables prioritizing quality, worker protections, and sustainable practices in public procurement processes.  
SD endorses the strengthened legal clarity through distinct rules for concessions and public contracts, ensuring member states' autonomy in organizing services of general economic interest under Treaty principles.  
SD fully approves the SME-friendly measures including contract division into smaller lots and electronic procurement systems, advancing their manifesto goals for equitable market access and reduced bureaucratic barriers.

GUE_NGL conditionally approves the procurement directive's inclusion of social/environmental criteria but requests amendments to Article 3 to mandate minimum quality standards as binding requirements rather than optional considerations.  

GUE_NGL absolutely rejects the concessions directive framework as inconsistent with public service protection principles, demanding explicit exclusion of water management from all liberalization clauses.  

This proposal conflicts with GUE_NGL's anti-privatization stance by enabling market competition in sectors where member states should retain sovereign control over essential services.  

The issue fails to address democratic accountability concerns, requiring deletion of provisions allowing tripartite negotiations without parliamentary amendments (reference paragraph 15c procedural rules).  

GUE_NGL rejects the prioritization of cost-efficiency metrics in Annex II, proposing replacement with mandatory social impact assessments aligned with 2022 Social Progress Protocol benchmarks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding a Commission proposal (COM(2011)0895) aimed at harmonizing internal market regulations under Articles 53(1), 62, and 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). It highlighted subsidiarity objections from the Swedish Parliament and the UK House of Commons, which argued the proposal exceeded EU competence. The resolution incorporated input from multiple parliamentary committees—Internal Market, International Trade, Employment, Industry, Transport, Regional Development, and Legal Affairs—as well as opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2012) and the Committee of the Regions (October 2012). Parliament adopted its first-reading position, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments, and instructed its President to transmit the decision to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing adherence to legislative procedures and subsidiarity principles.

title: Union Customs Code: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down the Union Customs Code (recast)
background: The European Commission proposed recasting the Union Customs Code in 2012 to modernize customs procedures, addressing administrative inefficiencies, evolving trade patterns, and digitalization needs across EU member states. The Parliament will discuss regulatory reforms to streamline customs operations and enhance cross-border trade coherence under the single market framework.

stances.stance:
EPP completely endorses the issue's alignment with EPP's commitment to eliminating arbitrary barriers in the single market, ensuring equal access for SMEs and service providers across all member states.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the prioritization of digitalization and simplified administrative procedures to strengthen cross-border services, reflecting EPP's 2023 agenda for SME competitiveness and youth employment.  
EPP completely endorses the harmonization of payment systems and professional qualification recognition as critical steps toward a truly unified internal market for services.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's focus on leveraging service sector growth to address unemployment, particularly through targeted support for digital entrepreneurship and intergenerational service models.  
EPP completely endorses the issue's framework for country-specific recommendations to accelerate implementation, ensuring compliance with EPP's principle of subsidiarity while maintaining single market integrity.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s procedural transparency framework, aligning perfectly with their commitment to accountable governance and interinstitutional cooperation.  
SD applauds the emphasis on consumer protection standards, which effectively advances their priority of safeguarding citizen welfare within a socially conscious internal market.  
SD endorses the balanced approach to national regulatory considerations, proposing a minor amendment to Article 3 to codify a horizontal social clause ensuring uniform workers’ rights protections across all member states.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with Lisbon Treaty principles on social market economies, urging explicit reference to collective bargaining rights in implementation guidelines to prevent competitive erosion of labor standards.  
SD welcomes the integration of national parliament consultations, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for subsidiarity in social service adaptations to local economic conditions.

ECR entirely agrees the issue's integration of internal market objectives with customs harmonization frameworks under Articles 33 and 207, perfectly aligning with ECR's longstanding commitment to frictionless trade and economic dynamism.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the emphasis on legislative transparency in recasting procedures, recognizing its critical role in maintaining institutional trust while advancing single-market efficiencies.  
ECR applauds the issue's operational linkage between customs modernization and service sector growth, a strategic priority demonstrated through ECR's advocacy for job-creating regulatory environments.  
ECR emphatically supports the issue's incorporation of consumer protection standards within customs mechanisms, effectively advancing ECR's principle of balancing market freedom with citizen safeguards.  
ECR commends the procedural rigor in retaining Parliament's oversight role under Article 114, which aligns perfectly with ECR's doctrine of accountable EU governance and subsidiarity adherence.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal as a vehicle for monopolistic service sector consolidation, totally disapproveing with their opposition to capitalist market domination.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's alignment with internal market mechanisms that accelerate worker exploitation through wage devaluation and rights erosion.  
The proposal overlooks critical protections for public services, which GUE_NGL considers non-negotiable achievements of social progress.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to learn from mass protests against similar measures like the 2006 Services Directive, which exposed public rejection of market-driven service liberalization.  
This approach contradicts GUE_NGL's principle that economic integration must prioritize labor rights over corporate profit interests.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2012)0064), adopting its first-reading stance under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, particularly Articles 33, 114, and 207, while incorporating recommendations from the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the Parliament, Council, and Commission. It emphasized the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements are planned, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural continuity. The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional dialogue and adherence to the recasting technique outlined in the 2001 Interinstitutional Agreement. The Parliament’s decision considered inputs from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (report A7-0006/2013) and the European Economic and Social Committee’s opinion of May 2012, prioritizing alignment with internal market objectives and consumer protection standards.

title: Single market governance: REPORT on Single Market governance within the European Semester 2014
background: The European Semester process, established in 2010 under the Europe 2020 strategy, involved annual assessments of member states' economic policies, with the Commission identifying persistent obstacles to Single Market integration in services, energy, transport, and digital sectors through reports from 2011-2013. The Parliament will discuss improving Single Market governance within the European Semester framework.

stances.stance:
EPP fully agrees the integration of Single Market governance as a third European Semester pillar, perfectly aligning with its agenda for structural reforms and competitiveness-driven growth.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on accelerating infringement issue through EU Pilot and SOLVIT, mirroring its 2024 Digital Single Market Action Plan priorities.  
EPP fully agrees the call for SME financing enhancements via COSME and Horizon 2020, reflecting its longstanding commitment to entrepreneurship as Europe's growth engine.  
EPP perfectly supports cross-border energy interconnectivity targets, directly advancing its Energy Union strategy for cost-competitive industrial policies.  
EPP fully backs mandatory alignment of national reform programs with Single Market goals, consistent with its Europe 2020 implementation roadmap for job creation.

EFD rejects fundamentally the issue's push for deeper Single Market integration, which they argue perpetuates the euro's destructive "one-size-fits-all" framework that has plunged southern Europe into Third World-like devaluation and social collapse, directly conflicting with the issue's economic convergence goals.  
EFD opposes the issue's reliance on EU regulatory enforcement, condemning it as bureaucratic overreach that ignores national sovereignty. They cite Italy's 42% youth unemployment and austerity-driven suicides as proof that Brussels-imposed measures exacerbate human suffering rather than alleviate it.  
EFD condemns the issue's emphasis on cross-border policy harmonization, advocating instead for dismantling the euro to restore national currency sovereignty. They highlight Greece's 800,000 citizens lacking healthcare as evidence that EU fiscal rigidity contradicts promises of social protection.  
EFD disputes the issue's assumption that Single Market governance can reduce fragmentation, pointing to Bulgaria's 12% unemployment and 50% humanitarian crisis as outcomes of EU-mandated austerity that fuels populist backlash against Brussels.  
EFD challenges the issue's alignment with Europe 2020 job-creation targets, noting that rigid EU structures have failed to address catastrophic unemployment, necessitating a return to sovereign economic policies rather than further centralization.

GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions the integration of Single Market governance as a third European Semester pillar, perfectly aligning with their vision of ecological-industrial transformation through cross-border energy networks and digital infrastructure modernization.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on stakeholder democracy, proposing enhanced civil society participation mechanisms to strengthen the legitimacy of country-specific recommendations and Europe 2020 monitoring.  
GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions binding ecological conditionality in national reform programs, urging explicit linkage between energy interconnectivity targets and fossil fuel phase-out timelines to accelerate the Just Transition.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for SME support through Horizon 2020, while proposing an amendment to prioritize green innovation clusters in cross-border value chain development.  
GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions the critique of austerity-driven Semester priorities, reframing it as an imperative to codify social equality metrics (wealth distribution, child poverty rates) alongside GDP growth in Annual Growth Survey evaluations.

GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the issue's alignment with austerity-driven macroeconomic governance that exacerbates social inequality and precarity.  
GUE/NGL rejects the Single Market integration framework for perpetuating export surplus imbalances favoring economies like Germany while imposing pension cuts and wage suppression on peripheral states.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's failure to mandate poverty-proof minimum wages/benefits despite explicitly citing social indicators, contradicting their anti-austerity principles.  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal's inconsistency with democratic participation demands by maintaining technocratic infringement procedures over public welfare priorities.  
GUE/NGL disputes the SME financing mechanisms (COSME/Horizon 2020) as inadequate without binding measures against financial speculation and labor deregulation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to strengthen Single Market governance by integrating it as a third pillar of the European Semester, alongside existing economic and budgetary frameworks, to drive sustainable growth and competitiveness. It emphasized the importance of addressing persistent obstacles in key sectors—services, energy, transport, digital markets, and financial services—through improved transposition and enforcement of EU legislation, enhanced stakeholder involvement, and targeted country-specific recommendations. The resolution highlighted the 0.6% average transposition deficit but criticized prolonged infringement proceedings, particularly in services (averaging 49.8 months), and called for faster resolution mechanisms, including expanded use of the EU Pilot system and SOLVIT network. It urged deeper integration of the digital single market, energy interconnectivity, and transport infrastructure, alongside measures to protect consumer rights, support SMEs through improved access to finance (noting COSME and Horizon 2020 programs), and promote industrial policy focused on innovation and cross-border value chains. The Parliament stressed the need for rigorous impact assessments, smarter regulation, and better monitoring via tools like the Online Single Market Scoreboard and annual integration reports, while advocating for reforms in public procurement, professional qualifications recognition, and retail financial services to reduce fragmentation and enhance cross-border mobility. It also called for stronger alignment of national reform programs with Single Market goals to bridge gaps in achieving Europe 2020 targets, particularly job creation and economic convergence.

title: Combating late payment in commercial transactions: REPORT on the implementation of Directive 2011/7/EU on combating late payment in commercial transactions
background: Persistent late payments in EU commercial transactions, particularly affecting SMEs, prompted the 2011 Late Payment Directive to establish payment deadlines and interest penalties. Despite reduced delays reported in 2016, ongoing SME liquidity challenges, insolvency risks, and uneven enforcement across member states persisted. The Parliament will discuss Directive implementation effectiveness in addressing payment delays and safeguarding SMEs.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s enforcement of 30-day payment terms for public authorities, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to shielding SMEs from systemic financial abuse by powerful entities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the mandatory transparency provisions as a critical safeguard against unfair trade practices, effectively advancing their priority of rebalancing power dynamics in commercial relationships.  
GREEN_EFA proposes augmenting public sector accountability by mandating real-time disclosure of overdue payments to increase pressure for compliance, enhancing the issue’s enforcement framework.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the emphasis on mediation services and digital payment solutions, recognizing these as vital tools to empower SMEs in line with their innovation-driven economic vision.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s job-creation potential through reduced payment delays, consistent with their agenda for sustainable, equitable growth across EU economies.

ALDE strongly accepts the issue’s emphasis on stricter enforcement of 30-day payment terms, which aligns perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to protecting SMEs from unfair financial practices and ensuring a balanced business climate.  
ALDE applauds the mandatory transparency measures requiring public and private sector payment behavior databases, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of fostering accountability and fair competition in commercial transactions.  
ALDE endorses the promotion of national mediation services as a critical mechanism to empower SMEs in dispute issue, reflecting ALDE's advocacy for accessible and confidential support systems to address payment delays.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity for public authorities to lead by example in adhering to prompt payment principles, strongly accepting the issue’s call to align public procurement rules with timely payment obligations.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the implementation guidelines to specify standardized operational frameworks for Member States’ mediation services, ensuring consistent accessibility and effectiveness across all EU regions without opposing the issue’s core objectives.

ECR strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on protecting SMEs from liquidity crises caused by late payments, aligning with their commitment to fostering fair market conditions for economic growth.  
ECR proposes stricter enforcement of the 30-day payment limit for public authorities, emphasizing that state entities must lead by example to maintain credibility in private sector transactions.  
ECR recommends prioritizing voluntary contractual solutions over rigid regulatory frameworks, advocating for enhanced SME training in credit management to empower businesses without undermining contractual freedom.  
ECR welcomes transparency measures on payment behavior but suggests allowing flexibility for businesses to negotiate terms mutually, provided statutory interest safeguards remain binding.  
ECR urges the Commission to address its own historical delays in payments before expanding enforcement mechanisms, ensuring EU institutions exemplify the standards they impose.

GUE_NGL strongly upholds the issue's emphasis on stricter enforcement mechanisms and administrative sanctions to combat late payments, aligning perfectly with their commitment to protecting SMEs from exploitative financial practices.  
GUE_NGL approves mandatory transparency measures on payment behavior as critical for addressing power imbalances between SMEs and larger corporations, effectively advancing their priority of economic fairness.  
GUE_NGL proposes enhancing awareness campaigns about Directive 2011/7/EU’s provisions to empower SMEs in asserting their rights, addressing the current low utilization of statutory remedies.  
GUE_NGL applauds the call for public procurement alignment with prompt payment principles, which matches their longstanding advocacy for equitable public-sector accountability.  
GUE_NGL endorses leveraging digital payment technologies and mediation services as practical steps to reduce transaction delays and bureaucratic burdens on SMEs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about persistent late payments in commercial transactions, particularly harming SMEs, which face liquidity issues, increased bankruptcy risks (1 in 4 EU bankruptcies linked to late payments), and unfair power imbalances with larger firms. It emphasized Directive 2011/7/EU’s role in setting payment terms (30 days for public authorities, 60 days for businesses), statutory interest (≥8% above ECB rates), and minimum €40 compensation for recovery costs, but noted inadequate enforcement, with 60% of businesses still paid late in B2B transactions and 95% of SMEs experiencing delayed payments. The resolution urged stricter national enforcement, including shorter payment terms (ideally 30 days), mandatory transparency on payment behavior, and administrative sanctions for non-compliance. It highlighted the economic cost of late payments, estimating €158 million daily savings and 6.5 million additional jobs if delays were reduced. Recommendations included promoting mediation services, SME training in credit management, leveraging digital payment technologies, and aligning public procurement rules with prompt payment principles. The Parliament also called for EU-wide guidelines to clarify ambiguous terms in the Directive, stronger synergies between late payment rules and sector-specific initiatives (e.g., food supply chains), and Commission action against non-compliant Member States, including ongoing infringement procedures against Greece, Slovakia, Spain, and Italy.

title: CE marked fertilising products: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down rules on the making available on the market of CE marked fertilising products and amending Regulations (EC) No 1069/2009 and (EC) No 1107/2009
background: The EU's 2003 fertiliser regulations limited CE marking to inorganic products, creating market fragmentation. Circular Economy Action Plan priorities emphasized waste-derived fertilisers. EU reliance on imported phosphate, often cadmium-contaminated and sourced from geopolitically sensitive regions like Morocco-occupied Western Sahara, raised sustainability and health concerns. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing CE-marked fertiliser standards to expand market access for organic/recycled products, reduce contaminants, and address strategic resource dependencies.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the proposed cadmium restrictions, arguing insufficient evidence of health risks and disproportionate economic harm to EU agriculture.  
EFDD opposes stringent heavy metal limits as counterproductive, citing higher international standards and unintended enrichment of non-EU competitors.  
EFDD fundamentally contests the issue's approach to waste-derived fertilisers, warning of unaddressed hazards from cadmium extraction byproducts.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the proposed cadmium reduction limits as critical alignment with public health protection and innovation in clean fertilizer technologies.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s harmonization goals but proposes amending Article 9 to explicitly prohibit any circumvention of REACH chemical safety standards in fertiliser composition.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the circular economy focus, noting cadmium-free fertilisers perfectly align with their 2023 soil health manifesto commitments.  
GREEN_EFA recommends adding a recital to ban biodegradable plastic mulch films, preventing microplastic soil contamination while maintaining market harmonization.  
GREEN_EFA approves the issue’s framework but urges stricter safeguards in Annex II to prevent indirect weakening of Nitrates Directive thresholds through nutrient management clauses.

SD strongly endorses the harmonization of CE marked fertilisers as a critical step toward circular agriculture, aligning with their commitment to sustainable resource reuse and reduced environmental impact.  
SD applauds the balanced approach to cadmium reduction timelines, ensuring both health protections through gradual contaminant limits and industrial adaptability, mirroring their 2023 agro-environmental policy priorities.  
SD proposes strengthening Article 4 to explicitly safeguard the Nitrates Directive’s integrity, ensuring fertilisation limits remain binding to prevent intensive farming practices and soil degradation.  
SD endorses mandatory CE labeling for organic fertilisers as a transparency milestone, advancing consumer safety and fair market access for innovative circular economy products.  
SD highlights the need for accelerated research funding (Amendment 12bis) to achieve sub-20mg/kg cadmium thresholds ahead of the 12-year deadline, transforming this into a competitive advantage for EU agriculture.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to prohibit CE marking for non-EU products, particularly those exploiting occupied Western Sahara's resources, which violates principles of sovereignty and anti-colonialism.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the elevated cadmium limits, citing carcinogenic risks and soil contamination that directly contradict the party's uncompromising stance on environmental and public health safeguards.  
GUE_NGL condemns the harmonization framework as structurally biased toward agribusiness monopolies, inconsistent with demands for democratized food systems prioritizing small-scale agroecological practices.  
GUE_NGL rejects the omission of chromium limits and tolerance for industrial waste in fertilizers, which perpetuates hazardous material cycles denounced in the party’s circular economy policies.  
GUE_NGL opposes the conformity assessment mechanisms as inadequately precautionary, demanding binding requirements for public-sector evaluations and full linguistic accessibility of labels to empower grassroots oversight.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning internal market and consumer protection matters, adopting its first-reading stance based on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s report (A8-0270/2017) and incorporating opinions from the Committees on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety; Agriculture and Rural Development; and International Trade. The resolution emphasized adherence to the Commission’s original proposal (COM(2016)0157) under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which aims to harmonize laws affecting the internal market. It called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its proposal, ensuring legislative transparency and parliamentary oversight. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring procedural compliance and inter-institutional coordination.

title: Cableway installations: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cableway installations
background: The EU's 2000 Cableways Directive faced divergent national transpositions, creating internal market barriers and regulatory inconsistencies. The Parliament will discuss a proposed regulation to modernize safety standards and harmonize technical requirements for cableway installations across member states.

EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's modernization of technical regulations, recognizing its critical role in maintaining Europe's global leadership in cableway manufacturing and sustainable transport solutions.  
EPP absolutely endorses the transition from directives to regulations, as emphasized by multiple members, ensuring uniform application across all Member States and eliminating fragmentation in safety protocols.  
EPP perfectly supports the economic foresight demonstrated in the issue, particularly its alignment with smart city development and job creation through standardized European safety certifications.  
EPP absolutely endorses the balance achieved between rigorous safety requirements and reduced bureaucratic burdens, reflecting its principle of fostering SME competitiveness while upholding high consumer safeguards.
